docs.title: A digital sketch grammar of Yawarana
docs.text:
A corpus-based, data-rich digital1 grammar of Yawarana developed and written by Florian Matter in collaboration with Natalia Cáceres Arandia and Spike Gildea.

This is its mkdocs-material version.

Other formats:

  • CLLD
  • PDF

Visit the github repo for bundled releases and the markup source.

  1. Craft your own. ↩

docs.title: Adverbs
docs.text:
• copredicative function
  • no person inflection
  • deriving aderbs: -ke ❔

docs.title: Postpositions
docs.text: • Koehn and Koehn 1986: 111 on Apalaí: "Particles follow words of any class other than the ideophone, and never occur as free forms or in isolation."

docs.title: Shared morphology
docs.text:
• shared prefixes between nouns and postpositions
  • shared clitics (?) with verbs

There are person indices shared between verbs one the one, and nouns and postpositions on the other hand:

  • u-
  • më-
  • (ej-)

ta- is only found in verbs, while i-/t- and y- are only found on nouns and postpositions. All shared morphemes are fairly recent innovations; all original inflectional morphology on verbs has disappeared. Person prefixes have been replaced, while the linker y-, formerly also present on transitive verbs, was reanalyzed as part of the verb stem. Even within this shared set, nouns and postpositions behave differently from verbs.

Behavior of person indices on different POS. clitic vi vt postp n 0 1 u1 1 / 2 / 3 1 / 2 1 / 2 1 / 2 / 3 ta-3 1 / 3 me2 1 / 2 1 / 2 2 1 / 2 i3 3 / o 1 / 3

docs.title: The Yawarana people and their language
Previous studies on the Yawarana language
Variation
docs.text:
Some corners of Yawarana grammar are subject to variation:

  • vowel system (2.1.2)
  • plural marking (4.2.2, 6.4, 7)
  • constituent order (16)
  • expression of verbal arguments (13, 4.2.4, 6.1)
  • presence or absence of the ergative marker ya (13)

docs.title: Multiclausal
docs.text:
Historically, the function of subordinate clauses was covered by nominalizations and adverbializations. For instance, a meaning like 'after I slept, I ate' was expressed as 'after my sleeping', the verb being a noun syntactically, followed by a postposition.

  • argument of the matrix clause
  • adverbial adjunct

  • relative clause

  • differences & similarities to simple verb clauses?

  • order of arguments re: the verb (and each other)
  • case marking patterns
  • indexation
  • clausal particles
  • +mapping between matrix and subordinate

docs.title: Negation
docs.text:
There are a number of negation strategies in Yawarana. The most general negator is the particle jra, which can negate a number of constructions. It occurs encliticized to transitive and intransitive verbs , nouns , adverbs , and postpositions .

    1. kukurujra tëwï kukuru =jra kuku -ru =jra answer-ipfv=neg tëwï tëwï 3pro ‘do not imitate (auto)’ (Historia de vida de una mujer y costumbres de los yabaranas : 124)
    2. uyarë wïrë wïnïkïrïjra uyarë u- yarë 1-alone wïrë wïrë 1pro wïnïkïrï =jra wïnïkï -rï =jra sleep-ipfv=neg ‘I did not sleep apart (auto)’ (Conversación sobre malos augurios y otros : 183)
    3. aaa, ijtarijra ta aaa aaa ah ijtari =jra i- jta -ri =jra 3-foot-pert=neg ta ta like ‘ah, without his legs (auto)’ (Cuento de Ochi y otros por MaFl : 36)
    4. entë ma teijpojra wejtane entë entë here.loc ma ma rst teijpo =jra teijpo =jra far=neg wejtane wej -tane cop-cncs ‘although it is close to here (auto)’ (Conversación sobre estudios : 35)
    5. toto waimu yayejra toto toto non_Indian waimu waimu -∅ language-pert yaye =jra yaye =jra loc=neg ‘not in Spanish (auto)’ (Conversation about family with María Flores and Pablo Pérez : 244)

On verbs, it sometimes occurs with an overt allomorph of -ri , sometimes its zero allomorph, shown in .

  1. wïrë wajyakïtïjra taro wïrë ta wïrë ya wïrë wïrë 1pro wajyakïtï =jra wajyakïtï -∅ =jra be_happy-ipfv=neg taro taro -∅ say-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro ta ta -∅ say-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro ya ya erg ‘I’m saying I am not happy.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 24)

This variation is found in other contexts as well, but the conditioning factors of the deletion are currently unknown (see 6.2.1). However, in the case of jra, it may occur for a different reason entirely. Historically, a verb suffixed with *-rï and followed by a particle *pïra was a distinct construction from a verb with an adverbializing negative suffix *-pïra and followed by a copula (Gildea and Meira 2016, Cáceres 2016).

docs.title: -ja
docs.text:
-ja is pluralized with the postverbal particle kontomo. It is the negative counterpart to -se.

❕

docs.title: Nonverbal predications
docs.text:
Gildea 2018: 366 distinguishes two main formal types of nonverbal predication in Cariban languages: juxtaposition and copular constructions.

  • juxtaposed NP + ADV or NP + LOC is found in Arara, Ikpeng, Ye'kwana, Wayana, and Apalaí
  • for PC:
    • Nsubj + Npred: nominal (juxtaposition) predication. Limited in functional domains.
    • Nsubj + cop + Adverbial (adverbs/postpositional phrases). Fairly unlimited.
  • Innovations:
    • Nsubj + cop + Npred (S&M 2009)
    • Nsubj + Adverbial

docs.title: Patterns
docs.text:
• "existential particles" (mëtë, mïntë, entë, ijtë)
    • etymologically locatives, used for existential function. they can co-occur with the existential negative pïrarë
    • also occur in locative function
    • also combine with postpositional locatives, though more often not part of the clause? ,
  • the copula...
    • almost always occurs with adverbs
      • counterexamples
      • not when negated
    • can occur with locatives and existential particles
      • fairly solid pattern of copula serving as a location for past marking existential function: compare mostly past with nonpast
      • however, no such pattern with locatives: copula and no copula show no salient distribution
    • almost never occurs with nouns
      • only counterexample: nppred cop with 'sick' ; can occur without cop, too
    • does not combine with pïrarë
      • one counterexample with partpred + pïrarë + cop + npsubj is with a concessive ❔
      • it does occur with pïnirë, though , ❔
    • is always present in subordinate clauses (chi-yawë 'when', chi-pëke 'because') ❔
      • even with nominal predicates: ,
      • one example of negation, occurs on additional copula
      • one example of chi chipokono
  • several negation strategies:
    • jra for adverbs and on nouns in the existential pïrarë np~subj~jra construction
    • pïnirë for nominal predicates and ones with locative particles
    • pïrarë for existential predicates
      • also for identification?
    • -ja or -jnari on the copula
  • order is fairly flexible; potentially rigid adv~pred~ np~subj~ cop, though negated counterexample
  • unclear role of manïkï in nppred + npsubj construction
  • construction with two copulas chi wejsapë? , , , ❕

docs.title: Pronouns
docs.text:
The personal pronouns of Yawarana are shown in Table 4.1. The system shows the usual Cariban inclusive/exclusive (1+2 and 1+3) distinction, though the 1+2 pronoun ejnë does not have the /k/ found elsewhere in the family. It is likely a reflex of an old copula + infinitive *eti-në. ❔ Regarding plural marking, it should be noted that kontomo, which appears on the second person plural pronoun, is usually restricted to verbs, while -santomo is only found with third person pronouns and demonstratives. ❔

Pronouns sg pl 1 wïrë 1+2 ejnë 1+3 ana 2 mërë monkontomo 3 tëwï tëwïsantomo

Reduced forms of the first and second person pronouns occur as proclitics/prefixes❔ attaching to nouns to indicate possessor (see 4.2.4), attached to verbs to indicate the A or P argument (see 6), or attached to postpositions to indicate the argument of the postposition (see 7.2). The occurrence of bound u- on members of all three parts of speech is illustrated in ; illustrates the same distribution for më-.

    1. irë nwa chipëkë usamori uyïpï incharë irë irë 3ana.inan nwa nwa thus chipëkë chipëkë because usamori u- samo -ri 1-cry-ipfv uyïpï u- yïpï -∅ 1-mountain-pert incharë in -charë see-imn ‘that's why I'm crying seeing my hills (auto)’ (Historia de vida de una mujer y costumbres de los yabaranas : 723)
    2. uyarë wïrë përemekïrï uyarë u- yarë 1-alone wïrë wïrë 1pro përemekïrï përemekï -rï talk-ipfv ‘I just talk.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 46)
    1. weroro wëra këyetari mëmukuru weroro weroro dog wëra wëra like këyetari -ri grow-ipfv mëmukuru më- muku -ru 2-child-pert ‘your children grow up like dogs (auto)’ (Historia de vida de una mujer y costumbres de los yabaranas : 160)
    2. mëtojpa wïrë mëtojpa më- tojpa -∅ 2-hit-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro ‘I will beat you to death (auto)’ (Historia de Pajarito y algunas preguntas sobre Tamanaco : 114)
    3. ¿ mëpana ma tataja wejsapë? mëpana më- pana 2-dat ma ma rst tataja ta- ta -ja 3p-say-neg wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pfv ‘didn't he say it directly to you? (auto)’ (Cuento de Ochi y otros por MaFl : 443)

The third person demonstrative pronouns or articles are shown in Table 4.2. ❔ None of them have shortened and phonologically bound counterparts.

Demonstrative pronouns / articles anim inan sg pl sg pl prox kërë kërësantomo eni enijne medial/near? michi / misi michisantomo / michitomo mërë dist mëjkï mëkïsantomo mëjnï mëjnijne
  • nominal interrogative pronouns: ❔
    • anïkï (with -santomo)
    • ati (no plural)

docs.title: Nominal inflection
docs.text: Nouns in Yawarana may bear suffixes marking their possession status (4.2.1), number (4.2.2), and nominal past tense (4.2.3). Possessed nouns may bear a person prefix, or the linker y- (4.2.4). ❕

docs.title: Suffixes for possessed and non-possessed nouns
docs.text:
In the possession construction in Yawarana, the possessor noun occurs immediately preceding the possessed noun, which is the head of the possession phrase. ❕ Alternatively, the possessor can appear as a prefix on the possessed noun. The possessor noun is never marked (for instance, with genitive case), but the possessed noun (the head) is often marked for being possessed by a suffix; an unambiguous label for this counterpart of the genitive is pertensive (Dixon 2010). The choice of suffix is lexically conditioned; while most nouns take -ri, some take -ti. Unpossessed nouns generally are unmarked, but some 15 nouns ❕ bear the suffix -të when they appear without a possessor.

Examples illustrate the possible patterns of markedness for nouns when possessed and unpossessed. The vast majority of nouns in our corpus are unmarked when unpossessed, but when possessed the suffix -ri occurs . A handful of nouns is marked with -ri/-ti when possessed and with -të when not possessed . Another handful is unmarked when possessed and marked with -të when not possessed . The fourth logical category, where neither possession or non-possession is marked, contains very few members (only one attested so far). For these nouns, the difference is marked only by the presence or absence of a possessive prefix or free-form possessor . ❕

  1. Nouns that take a suffix only when possessed: akajra-ri ‘X’s bow’ akajra ‘bow’ y-amaka-ri ‘X’s yucca’ amaka ‘yucca’ y-ántë-ri ‘X’s fishhook’ antë ‘fishhook’ y-ateri-ri ‘X’s garden/field’ ateri ‘garden/field’ ënu-ru ‘X’s eye’ ënu ‘eye’ y-ëpi-ri ‘X’s medicine’ ëpi ‘medicine’
  1. Nouns that take one suffix when possessed and another when unpossessed: yë-ri ‘X’s tooth’ yë-të ‘tooth’ pata-ri ‘X’s place’ pata-të ‘(part of name) San Juan de Manapiare’ y-ese-ti ‘X’s name’ ese-të ‘name’ y-ase-tï ‘X’s cord’ ase-të ‘cord’
  1. Nouns that take a suffix only when unpossessed: yëjpë ‘X’s bone’ yëjpë-të ‘bone’ petï ‘X’s thigh’ petï-të / pej-të ‘thigh’ y-aponi ‘X’s stool’ apon-të ‘stool’
  1. Nouns that never take a suffix, whether possessed or unpossessed: i-jmëy ‘his egg’ ëjmëy ‘egg’

docs.title: Nominal number
docs.text:
There are several pluralization strategies for nouns. One is the suffix -tomo (-tom, -ton), which occurs on both possessed and unpossessed nouns .

    1. wurijyantomo rë wejsapë ijtë wurijyantomo wurijyan -tomo woman-pl rë rë emp wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pfv ijtë ijtë there ‘there were only women (auto)’ (Conversación sobre los primeros tiempos de contacto : 123)
    2. tajne nankase takerejtomo ya tajne ta- jne 3-pl nankase nanka -se find-pst takerejtomo t- akere -j -tomo 3-relative-pert-pl ya ya erg ‘his relatives found him (auto)’ (Historia de Pajarito y algunas preguntas sobre Tamanaco : 131)

It can be combined with the plural particle jne ; this particle can also be the only exponent of plural .

  1. wïrë najpïtomojne, wurijyantomojne sënka wara rë wïrë wïrë 1pro najpïtomo =jne najpï -∅ -tomo =jne grandfather-pert-pl=pl wurijyantomo =jne wurijyan -tomo =jne woman-pl=pl sënka -∅ finish-acnnmlz wara wara thus rë rë emp ‘as my grandparents disappear, the women (auto)’ (Historia de vida de una mujer y costumbres de los yabaranas : 944)
  1. tipapëjsejne waijtajne tipapëjse =jne tipa -pëj -se =jne go_in_group-plur-pst=pl waijta =jne waijta =jne mouse=pl ‘the mice went away.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 40)

There is also the particle kontomo, which marks plurality of the possessor . Etymologically, it consists of an earlier *komo suffixed with -tomo.

  1. chimakontomo chima =kontomo chima =kontomo path=pl ‘their path’ (Historia de vida de una mujer y costumbres de los yabaranas : 539)

In many nouns, old plural markers have become lexicalized, like in wiriyamo or waraijtokomo, which show former *-yamë and *komo.

docs.title: Argument prefixes
docs.text:
Person prefixes on nouns are conditioned by the initial segment (Table 4.3). C-initial nouns take i-, and first and second person are bare u- and më-. On V-initial nouns, third person is marked with t-, and the first and second person prefixes combine with the linker y-. Some examples are shown in .

Possessive prefixes on nouns _C _V 1 u- u-y- 2 më- më-y- 3 i- t-
  1. uyïwïj yawë usenejkari sukuri jwama uyïwïj u- y- ïwïj -∅ 1-lk-house-pert yawë yawë loc usenejkari u- -ri 1-stay-ipfv sukuri sukuri silently jwama *** ‘I silently stay in my house.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 28)
  1. tïwïj yaka waraijtokomo manikijpë tïwïj t- ïwïj -∅ 3-house-pert yaka yaka all waraijtokomo waraijtokomo man manikijpë *** ‘He went to his house.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 46)
  1. pïrarë ti iwenaru wejsapë pïrarë pïrarë neg.exist ti ti hsy iwenaru i- wena -ru 3-vomit-pert wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pfv ‘their vomit was not there.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 19)

The linker also occurs with (pro-)nominal possessors:

  1. toto yoti tajtoj mare toto toto non_Indian yoti y- oti -∅ lk-meat-pert tajtoj taj -toj say-circ.nmlz mare ? ‘what they call the food of the criollos (auto)’ (Conversación cosas no indígenas : 52)
  1. ati ke ejnë yoti yamanë wejsapë tëwï ati ati what ke ke ins ejnë ejnë 1+2pro yoti y- oti -∅ lk-meat-pert yamanë yamanë -∅ make-ipfv wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pfv tëwï tëwï 3pro ‘with that we used to prepare the meat (auto)’ (Conversación cosas no indígenas : 126)

There are some nouns that preserve the old second person a- (Table 4.4).❕

Archaic possessive prefixes on nouns _C _V 1 u- u-y- 2 a- a-y- 3 i- t-

  • Gildea, Spike and Meira, Sérgio. 2016. A Comparative survey of Verbal Negation in the Cariban Family. (Talk held at Amazónicas VI).

  • Koehn, Edward and Koehn, Sally. 1986. Apalai. In Derbyshire, Desmond C. and Pullum, Geoffrey K. (eds.), Handbook of Amazonian Languages, 33–127. Berlin/New York: Mouton de Gruyter.

docs.title: First person
docs.text:
1. Preverbal pronoun wïrë yaruwarijra wïrë wïrë 1pro yaruwari =jra yaruwa -ri =jra laugh-ipfv=neg ‘I don’t laugh.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 4)
  1. Postverbal pronoun këyaja wïrë këyaja këya -ja think-neg wïrë wïrë 1pro ‘no sé (auto)’ (Conversación sobre malos augurios y otros : 298)
  1. Prefix uyïwïj yawë usenejkari sukuri jwama uyïwïj u- y- ïwïj -∅ 1-lk-house-pert yawë yawë loc usenejkari u- -ri 1-stay-ipfv sukuri sukuri silently jwama *** ‘I silently stay in my house.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 28)
  1. Preverbal pronoun and prefix aaa usukuru morone ta, wïrë usujta ta ne aaa aaa ah usukuru u- suku -ru 1-urine-pert morone morone hurting ta ta like wïrë wïrë 1pro usujta u- -∅ 1-urinate-ipfv ta ta like ne ne ints ‘My urine hurts, I will urinate.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 23)
  • not attested: prefixed verb followed by pronoun

docs.title: Second person
docs.text:
1. Prefix tototomo pata yaka mëtëja tototomo toto -tomo non_Indian-pl pata pata -∅ village-pert yaka yaka all mëtëja më- të -ja 2-go-neg ‘you can't (can't) go to the creoles' village (auto)’ (Conversation about family between AmGu and ElPe : 7)
  • not attested: pronoun

docs.title: Third person
docs.text:
1. Zero wïnïjse wïnïjse wïnïj -se sleep-pst ‘He slept.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 6)
  1. Preverbal NP irëjpë tëwï waijtatomo nwajtëri irëjpë irëjpë then tëwï tëwï 3pro waijtatomo waijta -tomo mouse-pl nwajtëri nwajtë -ri dance-ipfv ‘Then the mice were dancing.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 16)
  1. Postverbal NP wepïrï makë wepïrï wepï -rï come-ipfv makë makë mom ‘mi mamá comes (auto)’ (Conversation about dreams with IrDi and ElPe : 83)
  1. Preverbal pronoun tëwï nwajtënëpëkë tëwï tëwï 3pro nwajtënëpëkë nwajtë -nëpëkë dance-prog.intr ‘he... he was dancing all the time. (auto)’ (Descripción de la construcción de una casa e historia de la muerte de Agustín : 28)
  1. Postverbal pronoun ë'ë, tawara takï chapëtiri tëwï ë'ë ë'ë yes tawara tawara too takï takï cnfrm chapëtiri *** tëwï tëwï 3pro ‘yes, it also shouts that (auto)’ (Conversación sobre malos augurios y otros : 113)
  • të has an irregular third person marker ij-
  1. waraijtokon maniki irëjpë ijtëse waraijtokon waraijtokon man maniki maniki rel.anim irëjpë irëjpë then ijtëse ij- të -se 3-go-pst ‘Then the man went.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 45)

docs.title: Transitive clauses
docs.text:
There are several factors that play a role here:

  1. presence or absence of prefix
  2. presence or absence of pronouns and NPs
  3. order of free arguments
  4. presence or absence of ya

docs.title: Third on third
docs.text: 1. preverbal pronoun with ya tëwï ya nepïjpë wejsapë tëwï tëwï 3pro ya ya erg nepïjpë nepï -jpë bring-pst wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pfv ‘he brought it (auto)’ (Conversación cosas no indígenas : 132)

docs.title: Classes of verbs
docs.text:
Yawarana verb roots can be divided into those yielding an intransitive stem, and those yielding a transitive stem. The only inflectional criterion distinguishing the two classes is the third person prefix ta-, which only occurs (optionally, see 6.1.2) on transitive stems. Thus, transitive yawanka takes ta- , but intransitive yaruwa does not . ❔

    1. iyawë chipëkë, tayawankase iyawë i- yawë 3-loc chipëkë chipëkë because tayawankase ta- yawanka -se 3p-kill-pst ‘therefore, he killed her (auto)’ (Conversación sobre malos augurios y otros : 217)
    2. yaruwakontomo yatum ponoko yaruwa =kontomo yaruwa -∅ =kontomo laugh-ipfv=pl yatum yatum day ponoko *** ‘They laugh every day.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 42)
  • potential additional types:
    • detransitive
    • ditransitive
    • "n-adding"
    • accidental lability
    • irregular 'to go'
  • note that all transitive verbs are consonant‑initial, whether etymologically or not because y- is added to all vowel‑initial roots
  • the y‑ disappears when preceded by the detransitivizer ❕

docs.title: Verbalizing suffixes
docs.text: None of these are productive, although there are many lexemes derived with them.

docs.title: -ta / -na
docs.text:
-ta derives intransitive verbs (Table 5.1).

Lexemes derived with *-ta* Base Derivation suku sujta kaimo kaimota yoko yokota wereyi wereyta wanapu wanaputa sakau sakauta roko rokota punu punta pikë pikëta pichipichi pichipichita naki nakita muku mukuta moto motota moroni moronta mesuku mesujta këmu këmuta konopo konopota kawono kawonota chëkëy chëkëyta chimichimi chimichimita chikë chikëta awochi awochita asere asereta aijkorono aijkoronota ajpachi ajpachita akï akïta

docs.title: Person prefixes
docs.text:
Verbs are inflected for person with a set of prefixes, shown in Table 6.1. ❔ First and second person prefixes show ergative alignment, expressing s and p. Intransitive verbs are not overtly inflected for third person, while transitive verbs show an optional ta- in 3>3 scenarios.❕

Person marking prefixes on verbs intr tr 1 u- u- 2 më- më- 1+2 ej- ej- 3 ∅ ta-

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
• Second person A
    • më- marking A in
    • subordinate clauses and
    • is 'learn' transitive?
    1. michi ma mëyapëjjrama michi michi med.anim ma ma rst mëyapëjjrama më- yapëj -jrama 2-grab-proh ‘do not touch this (auto)’ (Cuento de Ochi y otros por MaFl : 324)
    2. mëinija ka, aniki pinchi, tënësem warai yichapë, okonotojpe mëinija më- ini -ja 2-see-neg ka ka q aniki aniki who pinchi pinchi hes tënësem *** warai warai like yichapë *** okonotojpe *** ‘you have not seen a fish that is put on to dry (auto)’ (Historia de vida de una mujer y costumbres de los yabaranas : 633)
    3. tëwï ma takï mëyakarama chijpë wararë kwa ta sënkatoj mëtë tëwï tëwï 3pro ma ma rst takï takï cnfrm mëyakarama më- -∅ 2-tell-ipfv chijpë chi -jpë cop-pst.acnnmlz wara =rë wara =rë thus=emp kwa kwa how ta ta like sënkatoj -toj finish-circ.nmlz mëtë ? ‘tell us again how they ended up there (auto)’ (Conversation about family with María Flores and Pablo Pérez : 13)
    1. mërë warë mëyënëtojpano ka uyakërë mërë wepïrï mërë mërë 2pro wa =rë wa =rë thus=emp mëyënëtojpano më- yënë -tojpano 2-eat(meat)-fut.concl ka ? uyakërë u- y- akërë 1-lk-with mërë mërë 2pro wepïrï wepï -rï come-ipfv ‘so for you to eat you came with me? (auto)’ (Conversación sobre malos augurios y otros : 43)
    2. mëyakarama mare mëyakarama më- -∅ 2-tell-ipfv mare mare rel.inan ‘the one you are saying (auto)’ (Cuento de la araña : 5)
    1. kwase mëëmpamïjpë ejnë waimu yaye kwase kwase how mëëmpamïjpë më- ëmpamï -jpë 2-learn-pst ejnë ejnë 1+2pro waimu waimu -∅ language-pert yaye yaye loc ‘how you learned our language (auto)’ (Conversation about family with María Flores and Pablo Pérez : 15)
    2. irëjpë, kwaraijyawë rë mëëmpamïjpë tajto marë ti? irëjpë irëjpë then kwaraijyawë *** rë rë emp mëëmpamïjpë më- ëmpamï -jpë 2-learn-pst tajto *** marë marë rel.inan ti ti hsy ‘Afterwards, when did you learn what you say? (auto)’ (Conversation about family with María Flores and Pablo Pérez : 238)
  • First person A
  1. uyepematojpe pïrarë wïrë inawë uyepematojpe u- yepema -tojpe 1-pay-purp pïrarë pïrarë neg.exist wïrë wïrë 1pro inawë inawë have ‘I can't afford to pay (auto)’ (Historia de vida de una mujer y costumbres de los yabaranas : 875)
  • Transitive local scenarios
    1. entë mëinpojra wïrë ya entë entë here.loc mëinpo =jra më- in -po -∅ =jra 2-see-des-ipfv=neg wïrë wïrë 1pro ya ya erg ‘I don't want to see them here (auto)’ (Conversación sobre malos augurios y otros : 231)
    2. mëini wïrë ya mëini më- ini -∅ 2-see-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro ya ya erg ‘te voy a ver (auto)’ (Conversación sobre malos augurios y otros : 232)
    3. tëwï ke ma mëyepema wïrë ya, ta ti ta tëwï tëwï 3pro ke ke ins ma ma rst mëyepema më- yepema -∅ 2-pay-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro ya ya erg ta ta -∅ say-ipfv ti ti hsy ta ta like ‘I'll pay you with this," he said (auto)’ (Cuento de Ochi y otros por MaFl : 283)
  • one attested case of ta- on the lexical verb of a -pëkë construction w/ 2nd person a on aux ❕
    • Ø‑ ‘3p’ with transitive verbs with 1a or 2a
  • one example of më- ‘2a’ on imperative verb ❕
  • *t‑V‑se is no more — the t‑ is gone, except in lexicalized items

docs.title: Main clause tense‑aspect‑mood‑polarity suffixes
docs.text:
Verbs in main clauses are inflected for TAMP with a set of suffixes, shown in Table 6.2. They are discussed in 6.2.1.

Verbal TAM suffixes Suffix Function -ri imperfective -jpë past -se past perfective -sapë perfect -sarë imminent future -nëpëkë prog.intr pëkë prog.tr ‑tojpano fut (-tojpe) fut -ja neg -se-mï ‘obligation’ -në impersonal S -topo Non-declarative suffixes Suffix Function ‑jrama proh -i juss -kë / ‑të-kë imp / imp.pl -ta / -tantë-kë imp.mot / imp.mot.pl

Misc:

  • -se=pano ‘pst=concl’
  • -saj=pano ‘pfv=concl’
  • -sarë=pano ‘imn=concl’

docs.title: -ri
docs.text:
• allomorphy:
    • most conservative form: -rï
    • /ï/ > /i/: -ri
    • phonetic loss: -∅
      • inconsistent zero before jra, see 9
      • consistent zero before kontomo
    • assimilation: -ru
  • gave rise to -ri
  • plural with kontomo
  • negated with jra , but potentially two distinct etymologies
  • emerging pattern: -ri with postverbal (possessed?) arguments?
  1. wïrë yaruwarijra wïrë wïrë 1pro yaruwari =jra yaruwa -ri =jra laugh-ipfv=neg ‘I don’t laugh.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 4)

docs.title: Semantics
docs.text:
• not specified for tense, just imperfective aspect:
    • past
    • future
    • gnomic/present?
  1. irëjpë tëwï waijtatomo nwajtëri irëjpë irëjpë then tëwï tëwï 3pro waijtatomo waijta -tomo mouse-pl nwajtëri nwajtë -ri dance-ipfv ‘Then the mice were dancing.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 16)
  1. ¿ kwase ejnë yaruwari? kwase kwase how ejnë ejnë 1+2pro yaruwari yaruwa -ri laugh-ipfv ‘How will we laugh?’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 6)
    1. wïrë yaruwarijra wïrë wïrë 1pro yaruwari =jra yaruwa -ri =jra laugh-ipfv=neg ‘I don’t laugh.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 4)
    2. uyïwïj yawë usenejkari sukuri jwama uyïwïj u- y- ïwïj -∅ 1-lk-house-pert yawë yawë loc usenejkari u- -ri 1-stay-ipfv sukuri sukuri silently jwama *** ‘I silently stay in my house.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 28)

docs.title: -jpë
docs.text:
• allomorphy: none? ❕
  • diachrony: from -jpë
  • negated with jra
  1. tëwïsantomo wïrë wejyatë këyetajpëjra tëwïsantomo tëwïsantomo 3pro.pl wïrë wïrë 1pro wejyatë *** këyetajpë =jra -jpë =jra grow-pst=neg ‘they did not grow up with me (auto)’ (Historia de vida de una mujer y costumbres de los yabaranas : 186)

docs.title: -se
docs.text:
• allomorphy: -se/-che
  • diachrony: from -se
  • negation: replaced with -ja (see also 9.1.1)
  1. wëjkaja, ana tëse neke ne wëjkaja wëjka -ja fall-neg ana ana 1+3pro tëse të -se go-pst neke neke cntr ne ne ints ‘no nos caimos, nosotros nos fuimos (auto)’ (Conversación sobre los primeros tiempos de contacto : 28)
  • plural: kontomo
  1. tipasekontomo warë irëjpë pïrarë tipase =kontomo tipa -se =kontomo go_in_group-pst=pl wa =rë wa =rë thus=emp irëjpë irëjpë then pïrarë pïrarë neg.exist ‘They left and were gone.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 30)

❔

docs.title: -sapë
docs.text:
• diachrony: from -sapë
  • distribution: only occurs on the copula?
  • allomorphy: -sapë and -saj
  • negation: with -ja on lexical verb ❔
  1. irë wejtane mujyampe patakaja wejsapë irë irë 3ana.inan wejtane wej -tane cop-cncs mujyam =pe mujyam =pe pregnancy=ess patakaja -ja take_out-neg wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pfv ‘despite this, she did not get pregnant (auto)’ (Cuento de la araña : 38)
  1. apatakaja pïnïka wejsapë apatakaja -ja come_out-neg pïnïka *** wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pfv ‘maybe she did not come out (pregnant) (auto)’ (Cuento de la araña : 39)
  1. tayakïjtëja pïnika wejsapë tayakïjtëja *** pïnika pïnika prob wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pfv ‘maybe he didn't sleep with her (auto)’ (Cuento de la araña : 40)
  • what about ? is that existential negation?
  1. pïrarë ti iwenaru wejsapë pïrarë pïrarë neg.exist ti ti hsy iwenaru i- wena -ru 3-vomit-pert wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pfv ‘their vomit was not there.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 19)

docs.title: -sarë
docs.text:
• once a converb, now 'imminent future'
  1. irëjpë ta ti ta konopo wejsarë konopo wejsarë irëjpë irëjpë then ta ta -∅ say-ipfv ti ti hsy ta ta like konopo konopo rain wejsarë wej -sarë come-imn konopo konopo rain wejsarë wej -sarë come-imn ‘Then they said: “it’s raining, it’s raining”.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 25)
  1. moyochi tasarë, moyochi chipokono kojpaye pïnika warotari moyochi moyochi spider(sp.) tasarë ta -sarë say-imn moyochi moyochi spider(sp.) chipokono chipokono because kojpaye at_night pïnika pïnika prob warotari warota -ri work-ipfv ‘called a spider, perhaps because the spider works at night. (auto)’ (Cuento de la araña : 25)

docs.title: Detransitive voice
docs.text:
• functions of detrz:

    • antipassive
    • passive
    • reflexive
    • reciprocal
    • anticausative

  • other strategies for removing participant:

    • -se-mï 'gnomic'
    • -në

  • what is not used for voice?

    • -sapë
    • participle

docs.title: Issues with transitivity
docs.text:
• ya occurs with intransitives
  • some transitive verbs occur with oblique-marked P arguments:
  1. ati rë warai mërë iniri, irëjpë mëyarika ti ati ati what rë rë emp warai warai like mërë mërë 2pro iniri ini -ri see-ipfv irëjpë irëjpë then mëyarika më- yarika -∅ 2-laugh-ipfv ti ti hsy ‘You see something and then you laugh.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 1)
  • some intransitive verbs can look like transitives:
  1. ¿ ati ejnë yaruwari? ati ati what ejnë ejnë 1+2pro yaruwari yaruwa -ri laugh-ipfv ‘What are we going to laugh about?’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 12)
  • not all transitive verbs take identifiable objects:
  1. wïrë inija ta rë wïrë wïrë 1pro inija ini -ja see-neg ta ta like rë rë emp ‘I haven’t seen.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 44)

docs.title: Transitive clauses
docs.text:
• clear tendency for VCop (as opposed to CopV)
  1. wïrë inija tëwï wïrë wïrë 1pro inija ini -ja see-neg tëwï tëwï 3pro ‘I did not see that (auto)’ (Historia de vida de una mujer y costumbres de los yabaranas : 615)

docs.title: Derivationalprocesse: ano-nominalization
docs.text:
• ID: anonmlz
  • Name: ano-nominalization
  • Language: Yawarana
Derivations
  • Yawarana eniro ‘now, today‘ → Yawarana eniro-no ‘now-NMLZ, today-NMLZ‘
  • Yawarana nop ‘good‘ → Yawarana nop-ano ‘good-NMLZ‘
  • Yawarana teijpo ‘far, long‘ → Yawarana teijpo-no ‘far-NMLZ, long-NMLZ‘

docs.title: Derivationalprocesse: Detransitivization
docs.text:
• ID: detrz
  • Name: Detransitivization
  • Language: Yawarana
Derivations
  • Yawarana nai ‘do‘ → Yawarana ëjnai ‘make self‘
  • Yawarana wenaka ‘vomit‘ → Yawarana ëjwenaka ‘vomit‘
  • Yawarana yerema ‘feed‘ → Yawarana serema ‘eat‘
  • Yawarana ënka ‘finish‘ → Yawarana sënka ‘finish‘
  • Yawarana nëmë ‘leave‘ → Yawarana ëjnëmë ‘remain‘
  • Yawarana enejka ‘watch‘ → Yawarana senejka ‘stay‘
  • Yawarana pataka ‘take out‘ → Yawarana apataka ‘come out‘
  • → Yawarana sereka ‘become tired‘
  • Yawarana ini ‘see‘ → Yawarana esene ‘see self‘
  • → Yawarana atapëj ‘seize on‘
  • Yawarana pënaka ‘return‘ → Yawarana ëjpënaka ‘return‘

• Historia de vida de una mujer y costumbres de los yabaranas

  • Descripción de la construcción de una casa e historia de la muerte de Agustín
  • Conversation about family between AmGu and ElPe
  • Conversación sobre malos augurios y otros

docs.title: Wordform: aaa ‘ah’
docs.text:
• ID: aaa-ah
  • Form: aaa
  • Parameter_ID: ah
  • Morpho_Segments: aaa
  • Language: Yawarana
MorphsExamples
  • Yawarana aaa ‘ah‘
  • aaa usukuru morone ta, wïrë usujta ta ne ‘My urine hurts, I will urinate.’
  • aaa, ijtarijra ta ‘ah, without his legs (auto)’

docs.title: Wordform: aniki ‘who?’
docs.text:
• ID: aniki-who
  • Form: aniki
  • Parameter_ID: who?
  • Morpho_Segments: aniki
  • Source: Mattéi-Müller and Cáceres Arandia 2023
  • Media_ID: YarLex_0044_PaPe_aniki-02

  • Yawarana aniki ‘who‘
  • aniki narëpe yakërë ejnë përemekïrï, ejnë pëkëpene, wanene ‘Who are we gonna talk to? We’re alone, aunt.’
  • mëinija ka, aniki pinchi, tënësem warai yichapë, okonotojpe ‘you have not seen a fish that is put on to dry (auto)’
